title-group.article-title: Book Review: Responsible Opioid Prescribing: A Clinician’s Guide

contrib.aff: Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, Nebraska

article-meta.product: Fishman SM . Responsible Opioid Prescribing: A Clinician’s Guide, 2nd edition, revised and expanded. Washington, DC: Waterford Life Sciences; 2012. pp. $16.95. (http://fsmb.org/cme/)

body.p: The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) now lists drug poisoning deaths as the leading cause of accidental death in adults in the United States, exceeding motor vehicle accidents (the result of a decline in motor vehicle–associated deaths due to greater automobile safety coupled with an increase in abuse of prescription drugs, particularly opiates). 1 Meanwhile, the number of such poisoning deaths has increased markedly among teenagers although not yet exceeding motor vehicle deaths. 2 The Federation of State Medical Boards has been advocating for physician education on this issue. To that end, the Federation of State Medical Boards Foundation has arranged for Scott Fishman, an anesthesiology-trained pain specialist, to update his brief and very readable handbook on the topic of proper opioid prescribing. Many child neurologists think this is not a subject of concern in their practices because most pain medications are prescribed in adult not pediatric medical practices. However, adolescents do obtain such prescriptions, and medications prescribed for adults in the household often end up in the hands of children or adolescents. Chapter 9 (“Prescription Drug Misuse Among Young People”) of the book addresses this issue. Disturbingly, one in five US high school students had taken an abuse-potential prescription drug without a physician’s prescription during the year 2009. Thus, this is a book that should be read by all practicing physicians, including child neurologists.
